entry.et: Middle English, from Old English findan; akin to Old High German findan to find, Latin pont-, pons bridge, Greek pontos sea, Sanskrit patha way, course

def.dt: :to come upon often accidentally :encounter
:to meet with (a particular reception) hoped to find favor
:to come upon by searching or effort must find a suitable person for the job
:to discover by study or experiment find an answer
:to obtain by effort or management find the time to study
:attain reach the bullet found its mark
:to discover by the intellect or the feelings :experience find much pleasure in your company
:to perceive (oneself) to be in a certain place or condition
:to gain or regain the use or power of trying to find his tongue
:to bring (oneself) to a realization of one's powers or of one's proper sphere of activity must help the student to find himself as an individual N. M. Pusey
:provide supply
:to furnish (room and board) especially as a condition of employment
:to determine and make a statement about find a verdict found her guilty
:to determine a case judicially by a verdict find for the defendant
:to criticize unfavorably
:an act or instance of finding
:something found: as
:a valuable discovery an archaeological find
:a person whose ability proves to be unexpectedly good
:to learn by study, observation, or search :discover
:to catch in an offense (as a crime) the culprits were soon found out
:to ascertain the true character or identity of the informer was found out
:to discover, learn, or verify something I don't know, but I'll find out for you
